args: Is this article primarily about a new action or announcement by the Trump administration/White House/Executive? Respond simply with "yes" or "no" . Johnson: House GOP to meet tonight after ‘productive’ meeting with Trump on budget House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) said House Republicans’ five-hour meeting Thursday with President Donald Trump was “very productive,” predicting that lawmakers will soon be able to announce how they plan to advance the president’s agenda. “The president started off the meeting and sort of set the table for the discussion,” Johnson told reporters on Capitol Hill. “We’ve got out the whiteboards, and we worked out the framework for what we believe will be the path forward, and we’re going to meet again tonight to finish up some final details.” House Republicans have been working to find agreement within their ideologically divisive majority on a budget resolution that would set the fiscal parameters necessary to package Trump’s legislative agenda in one bill. Republican senators have said they intend to move forward on approving components of Trump’s agenda in two bills next week. Johnson urged GOP senators to “allow the House to do its work,” as House Republicans fret that if they do not reach an agreement, the Senate will jam them with its fiscal and policy preferences. “We are moving this as quickly and as expeditiously as possible,” he continued. “ … We’re really grateful to the president for leaning in and doing what he does best, and that is put a steady hand at the wheel and get everybody working.” White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Thursday afternoon that Trump outlined his tax priorities early in the meeting to lawmakers: eliminating taxes on tips, Social Security and overtime pay, as well as renewing individual portions of the 2017 Trump tax cuts, which are set to expire at the end of 2025. Nonpartisan experts estimate that the initiatives proposed by Trump will lead to a $9 trillion increase in the national debt over 10 years, which rankles fiscal hawks demanding steeper cuts in negotiations.
